humanum_full_description_en:
The inscription of the word " riding " is made from " horse " and " singular " sound. The lower part of " horse " is made " two ". It is used in the Six Kingdoms during the Warring States Period.

Bronze writing is used as the original meaning, as a riding horse, seen in the riding festival.

Ancient books use its original meaning, such as "Warring States Policy. "Zhao Ce II": "Today I will ride and shoot Hu Fu to teach the people"; also use extended meaning to sit on the straddle, such as "Historical Records. Yuan Angpi Wrong Biography: "The Son of One Hundred Gold Does Not Ride Heng", Sima Zhensuoyin: "Wei Zhaoyun: "Height, truck weighs. Ride, it means cross.""
humanum_short_description_en: Bronze and seal scripts start with the sound of " horse " and " odd ". The original meaning is horse riding, that is, the two legs are split and straddle the horse.
humanum_full_description:
「騎」字金文從「馬」，「奇」聲，「馬」下部省作「二」，習見於戰國時六國文字。

　　金文用作本義，作乘騎之騎，見於騎傳馬節。

　　古書用其本義，如《戰國策．趙策二》：「今吾將胡服騎射，以教百姓」；亦用引申義跨坐，如《史記．袁盎鼂錯列傳》：「百金之子不騎衡」，司馬貞索隱：「韋昭云：『衡，車衡也。騎，謂跨之。』」
humanum_short_description: 金文與篆文從「馬」，「奇」聲，本義為騎馬，即兩腿分張，跨在馬上。
